title: Contributing to modsem
text: Thank considering contributing modsem! welcome contributions help improve package estimating interaction effects structural equation modeling (SEM). ensure smooth collaboration, please follow guidelines .

title: Contributing to modsem
text: Fork repository GitHub. Clone fork local machine.
code: git clone https://github.com/your-username/modsem.git cd modsem

title: Contributing to modsem
text: Ensure R installed machine. Install package dependencies. Install modsem package local repository.
code: install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_deps() devtools::install()

title: Contributing to modsem
text: Always create new branch work.
code: git checkout -b your-branch-name

title: Contributing to modsem
text: Make changes codebase. Ensure changes well-documented. Write tests changes applicable.

title: Contributing to modsem
text: also encourage contributions vignettes. new use case example, feel free add alter vignettes help demonstrate functionality modsem.

title: Contributing to modsem
text: Run tests ensure changes break existing functionality.
code: devtools::test()

title: Contributing to modsem
text: Push changes fork. Open pull request GitHub main branch original repository.
code: git push origin your-branch-name

title: Contributing to modsem
text: Provide clear descriptive title pull request. Describe changes made necessary. Reference related issues pull requests. Ensure tests pass merge conflicts.

title: Contributing to modsem
text: encounter issues suggestions improvements, please open issue GitHub. Provide much detail possible help us understand address issue.

title: customizing interaction terms
text: default, modsem() creates possible combinations product indicators. However, another common approach match indicators order. example, let’s say interaction latent variables X Z: X =~ x1 + x2 Z =~ z1 + z2. default, get XZ =~ x1z1 + x1z2 + x2z1 + x2z2. prefer use matching approach, expect XZ =~ x1z1 + x2z2 instead. achieve , can use match = TRUE argument.
code: m2 <- ' # Outer Model X =~ x1 + x2 Y =~ y1 + y2 Z =~ z1 + z2  # Inner model Y ~ X + Z + X:Z  '  est2 <- modsem(m2, oneInt, match = TRUE) summary(est2) #> modsem (version 1.0.11, approach = text: want even control, can use get_pi_syntax() get_pi_data() functions extract modified syntax data modsem(), allowing modify needed. can particularly useful cases want estimate model using feature lavaan isn’t available modsem(). example, syntax ordered multigroup models (now) isn’t flexible modsem() lavaan. can modify auto-generated syntax (along altered dataset) modsem() suit needs. generated syntax data can used estimate model using lavaan, giving user control arguments passed onto lavaan::sem(), potentially ability modify generated syntax data.

title: estimation alternatives using the LMS approach
text: default (v1.0.9) LMS approach uses accelerated EM procedure ("EMA") uses Quasi-Newton Fisher Scoring optimization steps needed. desireable, can switched standard Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm, setting algorithm = "EM". default LMS approach also uses fixed Gauss-Hermite quadrature, estimate numerical approximation log-likelihood. Instead fixed quadrature, possible use quasi-adaptive quadrature instead. Due performance reasons, adaptive quadrature fit individual quadrature participant, instead one entire sample (EM iteration), based whole sample densities likelihood function. essentially works removing irrelevant nodes don’t contribute integral, increasing number nodes actually contribute integral. usually means nodes placed towards center distribution, compared standard fixed Gauss-Hermite quadrature. Using EMA adaptive quadrature might yield estimates closer results Mplus. model struggles converge, can try changing EM procedure setting algorithm = "EMA", algorithm = "EM", adaptive.quad = TRUE modsem() function. Additionally possible tweak parameters: max.iter: Maximum number iterations EM algorithm (default 500). max.step: Maximum number steps used Maximization step EM algorithm (default 1). convergence.rel: Relative convergence criterion EM algorithm. convergence.abs: Absolute convergence criterion EM algorithm. nodes: Number nodes numerical integration (default 24). Increasing number can improve accuracy estimates, especially complex models. quad.range: Integration range quadrature. Smaller ranges means integral focused. Applies using quasi-adaptive quadrature. adaptive.frequency: often quasi-adaptive quadrature calculated? Defaults every third EM iteration. can see example using TPB_UK dataaset, troublesome estimate simulated TPB dataset.
code: tpb_uk <- " # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)   ATT =~ att3 + att2 + att1 + att4   SN =~ sn4 + sn2 + sn3 + sn1   PBC =~ pbc2 + pbc1 + pbc3 + pbc4   INT =~ int2 + int1 + int3 + int4   BEH =~ beh3 + beh2 + beh1 + beh4  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC   BEH ~ INT:PBC "  fit <- modsem(tpb_uk,                data = TPB_UK,                method = "lms",                nodes = 32, # Number of nodes for numerical integration               adaptive.quad = TRUE, # Use quasi-adaptive quadrature               adaptive.frequency = 3, # Update the quasi-adaptive quadrature every third EM-iteration               algorithm ="EMA", # Use accelerated EM algorithm (Default)               convergence.abs = 1e-4, # Relative convergence criterion               convergence.rel = 1e-10, # Relative convergence criterion               max.iter = 500, # Maximum number of iterations               max.step = 1) # Maximum number of steps in the maximization step summary(fit) #> Estimating baseline model (H0) #>  #> modsem (version 1.0.11): #>  #>   Estimator                                         LMS #>   Optimization method title: fit measures for LMS and QML
text: vignette demonstrates evaluate compare model fit latent interaction models estimated via Latent Moderated Structural Equations (LMS) approach. Quasi-Maximum Likelihood (QML) approach. using modsem package (v≥1.0.8). standard Chi-square statistics available LMS/QML, assess fit : Examining fit indices baseline (-interaction) model. Conducting likelihood-ratio difference test compare baseline interaction models (Klein & Moosbrugger, 2000; Klein & Múthen, 2007). baseline model shows acceptable fit adding latent interaction significantly improves fit, interaction model can also deemed well-fitting.

title: fit measures for LMS and QML
text: define model three latent variables (X, Y, Z) interaction (X:Z):
code: m1 <- " # Outer (measurement) model X =~ x1 + x2 + x3 Y =~ y1 + y2 + y3 Z =~ z1 + z2 + z3  # Inner (structural) model Y ~ X + Z + X:Z "  # Estimate the full (H1) model via LMS est_h1 <- modsem(m1, oneInt, method = "lms")  # Estimate the baseline (H0) model without interaction est_h0 <- estimate_h0(est_h1, calc.se = FALSE) # std.errors are not needed

title: fit measures for LMS and QML
text: get fit measures baseline model can use fit_modsem_da() function. can also used get fit measures full model, pared chisq = FALSE avoid Chi-square test. set TRUE calculate Chi-square test ignoring interaction terms model.

title: fit measures for LMS and QML
text: Compare H0 vs. H1 using log-likelihood ratio test: significant p-value indicates latent interaction term significantly improves model fit.

title: fit measures for LMS and QML
text: convenience, can also use modsem_inspect() function = "fit" get fit indices models, comparative fit one go.

what: Interaction between two higher order constructs
title: higher order interactions
text: WARNING: Please note literature higher order interactions product indicator approaches virtually non-existant, likely need experiment different approaches find one works. well experiment adding constraints model. modsem two datasets variants Theory Planned Behaviour (TPB) dataset. TPB_2SO contains two second order constructs, INT (intention) second order construct ATT (attitude) SN (subjective norm), PBC (perceived behavioural control) second order construct PC (perceived control) PB (perceived behaviour).

what: Interaction between a first order and a higher order construct
title: higher order interactions
text: TPB_1SO dataset, INT construct second order construct ATT, SN PBC. example, estimate interaction INT (higher order construct) PBC (first order construct).

title: interaction effects between endogenous variables
text: Interaction effects two endogenous (.e., dependent) variables work expect product indicator methods ("dblcent", "rca", "ca", "uca"). However, lms qml approaches, straightforward. lms qml approaches can (default) handle interaction effects endogenous exogenous (.e., independent) variables, natively support interaction effects two endogenous variables. interaction effect exists two endogenous variables, equations easily written “reduced” form, meaning normal estimation procedures won’t work.

title: interaction effects between endogenous variables
text: Despite limitations, workaround lms qml approaches. Essentially, model can split two parts: one linear one non-linear. can replace covariance matrix used estimation non-linear model model-implied covariance matrix linear model. allows treat endogenous variable exogenous—provided can expressed linear model.

title: interaction effects between endogenous variables
text: Let’s consider theory planned behavior (TPB), wish estimate quadratic effect INT BEH (INT:INT). can use following model: Since INT endogenous variable, quadratic term (.e., interaction effect ) involve two endogenous variables. result, normally able estimate model using lms qml approaches. However, can split model two parts: one linear one non-linear. INT endogenous variable, can expressed linear model since affected interaction terms: can remove part original model, giving us: Now, can estimate non-linear model since INT treated exogenous variable. However, incorporate structural model INT. address , can instruct modsem replace covariance matrix (phi) (INT, PBC, ATT, SN) model-implied covariance matrix linear model estimating models simultaneously. achieve , use cov.syntax argument modsem:
code: tpb <- '  # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)   ATT =~ att1 + att2 + att3 + att4 + att5   SN =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC    BEH ~ INT:INT ' tpb_linear <- 'INT ~ PBC + ATT + SN' tpb_nonlinear <- '  # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)   ATT =~ att1 + att2 + att3 + att4 + att5   SN =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   BEH ~ INT + PBC    BEH ~ INT:INT ' est_lms <- modsem(tpb_nonlinear, data = TPB, cov.syntax = tpb_linear,                    method = "lms") #> Warning: It is recommended that you have at least 48 nodes for what: The Latent Moderated Structural Equations (LMS) and the Quasi Maximum Likelihood (QML) Approach
title: LMS and QML approaches
text: LMS QML approaches work models, interaction effects endogenous variables can tricky estimate (see vignette). approaches, particularly LMS approach, computationally intensive partially implemented C++ (using Rcpp RcppArmadillo). Additionally, starting parameters estimated using double-centering approach, means observed variables used generate good starting parameters faster convergence. want monitor progress estimation process, can use verbose = TRUE.

title: LMS and QML approaches
text: example complex model based theory planned behavior (TPB), includes two endogenous variables interaction endogenous exogenous variable. estimating complex models LMS approach, recommended increase number nodes used numerical integration. default, number nodes set 16, can increased using nodes argument. nodes argument effect QML approach. interaction effect endogenous exogenous variable, recommended use least 32 nodes LMS approach. can also obtain robust standard errors setting robust.se = TRUE modsem() function. NOTE: want LMS approach produce results similar possible Mplus, consider increasing number nodes using nodes argument, using quasi-adaptive quadrature setting adaptive.quad=TRUE.

att3 + att4 + att5   SN =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC title: non-centered interaction terms (LMS and QML)
text: Using LMS QML approaches possible estimate interaction terms means latent variables centered (.e., non-zero means). can see example using TPB dataset: Comparing estimates get PBC INT zero means, see coefficients BEH~PBC BEH~INT drastically changed. bug, function interaction effect rescaling coefficients, centered zero. using standardized_estimates function, summary(est, standardized = TRUE) interaction effect centered, can see coefficients BEH~PBC BEH~INT rescaled .

title: methods
text: Note constraints can become quite complicated complex models, particularly interaction including enodgenous variables. method can therefore quite slow. "uca" = unconstrained approach (Marsh, 2004) "rca" = residual centering approach (Little et al., 2006) default "pind" = basic product indicator approach (recommended)

title: methods
text: "lms" = Latent Moderated Structural equations (LMS) approach, see vignette "qml" = Quasi Maximum Likelihood (QML) approach, see vignette estimates model Mplus, installed
code: m1 <- ' # Outer Model X =~ x1 + x2 + x3 Y =~ y1 + y2 + y3 Z =~ z1 + z2 + z3  # Inner model Y ~ X + Z + X:Z  '  # Product Indicator Approaches modsem(m1, data = oneInt, method = "ca") modsem(m1, data = oneInt, method = "uca") modsem(m1, data = oneInt, method = "rca") modsem(m1, data = oneInt, method = "dblcent")  # Distribution Analytic Approaches modsem(m1, data = oneInt, method = "mplus") modsem(m1, data = oneInt, method = "lms") modsem(m1, data = oneInt, method = "qml")

title: modsem
text: modsem introduces new feature lavaan syntax—semicolon operator (:). semicolon operator works way lm() function. specify interaction effect two variables, join Var1:Var2. Models can estimated using one product indicator approaches ("ca", "rca", "dblcent", "pind") using latent moderated structural equations approach ("lms") quasi maximum likelihood approach ("qml"). product indicator approaches estimated via lavaan, lms qml approaches estimated via modsem .

title: modsem
text: simple example specify interaction effect two latent variables lavaan. default, model estimated using "dblcent" method. want use another method, can change using method argument.

title: modsem
text: modsem allows estimate interactions latent variables also observed variables. , first run regression observed variables, interaction x1 z2, run equivalent model using modsem().

title: modsem
text: complex example using theory planned behavior (TPB) model. example includes two quadratic effects one interaction effect, using jordan dataset. dataset subset PISA 2006 dataset. Note: approaches also work may quite slow depending number interaction effects, particularly LMS constrained approaches.
code: tpb <- '  # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)   ATT =~ att1 + att2 + att3 + att4 + att5   SN =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC + INT:PBC   '  # The double-centering approach est_tpb <- modsem(tpb, TPB)  # Using the LMS approach est_tpb_lms what: The Latent Moderated Structural Equations (LMS) and the Quasi Maximum Likelihood (QML) Approach
title: observed variables in the LMS- and QML approach
text: contrast approaches, LMS QML approaches designed handle latent variables . Thus, observed variables used easily approaches. One way get around specifying observed variable latent variable single indicator. modsem() , default, constrain factor loading 1 residual variance indicator 0. difference latent variable indicator, assuming exogenous variable, zero-mean. approach works LMS QML methods cases, two exceptions.

title: observed variables in the LMS- and QML approach
text: LMS approach, can use -mentioned method almost cases, except using observed variable moderating variable. LMS approach, typically select one variable interaction term moderator. interaction effect estimated via numerical integration n quadrature nodes moderating variable. However, process requires moderating variable error term, distribution moderating variable modeled X∼N(Az,ε)X \sim N(Az, \varepsilon), AzAz expected value XX quadrature point k, ε\varepsilon error term. error term zero, probability observing given value XX computable. instances, first variable interaction term chosen moderator. example, interaction term "X:Z", "X" usually chosen moderator. Therefore, one variables latent, place latent variable first interaction term. variables observed, must specify measurement error (e.g., "x1 ~~ 0.1 * x1") indicator first variable interaction term. forget specify measurement error indicator first variable interaction term, receive error message. Note: get error message X/x1, since Z modelled moderating variable example.

  Y =~ y1 # Y is observed   x1 ~~ 0.1 * x1 # Specify a variance for the measurement error  # Inner model   Y ~ X + Z   Y ~ X:Z '  lms2 <- modsem(m2, oneInt, method = "lms") summary(lms2) #> Estimating title: plotting interaction effects
text: Interaction effects can plotted using included plot_interaction() function. function takes fitted model object names two variables interacting. function plot interaction effect two variables, : x-variable plotted x-axis. y-variable plotted y-axis. z-variable determines points effect x y plotted. function also plot 95% confidence interval interaction effect. Note vals_z argument (well values x) scaled mean standard deviation variables. Unless rescale argument set FALSE. simple example using double-centering approach:  different example using lms approach theory planned behavior model:
code: m1 <- " # Outer Model   X =~ x1   X =~ x2 + x3   Z =~ z1 + z2 + z3   Y =~ y1 + y2 + y3  # Inner Model   Y ~ X + Z + X:Z " est1 <- modsem(m1, data = oneInt) plot_interaction(x = "X", z = "Z", y = "Y",                  vals_z = -3:3, model = est1) tpb <- " # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)   ATT =~ att1 + att2 + att3 + att4 + att5   SN =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC   BEH ~ PBC:INT "  est2 <- modsem(tpb, TPB, method = "lms") #> Warning: It is recommended that you have at least 32 nodes for interaction #> effects between exogenous and endogenous variables in the lms approach 'nodes = #> 24' plot_interaction(x = "INT", z = "PBC", y = "BEH",                  vals_z = c(-0.5, 0.5), model = est2)

title: plotting interaction effects
text: plot_jn() function can used plot Johnson-Neyman regions given interaction effect. function takes fitted model object, names two variables interacting, name interaction effect. function plot Johnson-Neyman regions interaction effect. plot_jn() function also plot 95% confidence interval interaction effect. x name x-variable, z name z-variable, y name y-variable. model fitted model object. argument min_z max_z used specify range values moderating variable. example using ca approach Holzinger-Swineford (1939) dataset:  another example using qml approach theory planned behavior model:
code: m1 <-  '    visual  =~ x1 + x2 + x3    textual =~ x4 + x5 + x6   speed   =~ x7 + x8 + x9    visual ~ speed + textual + speed:textual '  est1 <- modsem(m1, data = lavaan::HolzingerSwineford1939, method = "ca") plot_jn(x = "speed", z = "textual", y = "visual", model = est1, max_z = 6) tpb <- " # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)   ATT =~ att1 + att2 + att3 + att4 + att5   SN =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC   BEH ~ PBC:INT "  est2 <- modsem(tpb, TPB, method = "qml") plot_jn(x = "INT", z = "PBC", y = "BEH", model = est2,          min_z = -1.5, max_z = -0.5) #> Warning: Truncating SD-range on the right and left!

title: plotting interaction effects
text: plot_surface() function can used plot 3D surface plots given interaction effect. function takes fitted model object, names two variables interacting, name dependent variable. function plot 3D surface plot interaction effect.
code: tpb <- " # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)   ATT =~ att1 + att2 + att3 + att4 + att5   SN =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC   BEH ~ PBC:INT "  est2 <- modsem(tpb, TPB, method = "qml") plot_surface(x = "INT", z = "PBC", y = "BEH", model = est2)

title: quadratic effects
text: Quadratic effects essentially special case interaction effects—variable interacts . , methods modsem can also used estimate quadratic effects. simple example using LMS approach. example, simple model two quadratic effects one interaction effect. estimate model using QML double-centering approaches, data subset PISA 2006 dataset. NOTE: can also use LMS approach estimate model, lot slower, since integrate along ENJ SC. first example sufficient integrate along X, addition SC:SC term means explicitly model SC moderator. means (default) integrate along 24^2=576 nodes. affects optimization process, also dramatically affects computation time standard errors. make estimation process possible reduce number quadrature nodes, calculate standard errors using outer product score function, instead negative hessian matrix. Additionally, can also pass mean.observed = FALSE, constraining intercepts indicators zero.

title: reliability-corrected single items
text: wanted, indicators latent variables can replaced reliablity corrected single items, using Chronbach’s α\alpha. can either done using relcorr_single_item function, returning altered model syntax data, via rcs argument modsem. can see example using relcorr_single_item function: can see relcorr_single_item returns new model syntax, new data.frame containing generated items. Additionally, also returns Chronbach’s α\alpha average variance extraced (AVE) different constructs model. syntax data can extracted using $ operator, used estimate model. Alternatively, possible use rcs argument modsem function call relcorr_single_item estimating model.
code: tpb_uk <- " # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)  ATT =~ att3 + att2 + att1 + att4  SN =~ sn4 + sn2 + sn3 + sn1  PBC =~ pbc2 + pbc1 + pbc3 + pbc4  INT =~ int2 + int1 + int3 + int4  BEH =~ beh3 + beh2 + beh1 + beh4  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)  INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC  BEH ~ INT + PBC  BEH ~ INT:PBC "  corrected <- relcorr_single_item(syntax = tpb_uk, data = TPB_UK) corrected #> Average Variance Extracted: #>   ATT:    0.773 #>   SN:     0.759 #>   PBC:    0.765 #>   INT:    0.790 #>   BEH:    0.769 #>  #> Chronbach's Alpha: #>   ATT:    0.941 #>   SN:     0.917 title: simple slopes analysis
text: Simple slope effects can plotted using included plot_interaction() function. function takes fitted model object names two variables interacting. function plot interaction effect two variables, : x-variable plotted x-axis. y-variable plotted y-axis. z-variable determines points effect x y plotted. function also plot 95% confidence interval interaction effect. Note vals_z argument (well values x) scaled mean standard deviation variables. Unless rescale argument set FALSE. simple example using double-centering approach:  want see numerical values simple slopes, can use simple_slopes() function: simple_slopes() function returns simple_slopes object. two methods/generics: print.simple_slopes(), prints simple slopes easy--read format .data.frame.simple_slopes(). print() method print predicted values, also significance tests difference slope lowest value z slope highest value z, well significance tests slope x different values vals_z. example , can see significant difference slope -1 * sd(Z) +1 * sd(Z). Note default vals_z rescaled mean standard deviation variable, unless rescale = FALSE set. means values vals_z interpreted standard deviations mean Z. want extract simple slopes data.frame, can use .data.frame() function:

title: Latent Interaction (and Moderation) Analysis in Structural Equation Models (SEM)
text: modsem available CRAN GitHub, can installed follows: Note: package needs compiled source macOS Linux. issues installing package macOS, might need install gfortran compiler. C++ compiler also required, installed default systems. See R macOs page information.
code: # From CRAN  install.packages("modsem")  # Latest version from GitHub install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("kss2k/modsem", build_vignettes = TRUE)

title: Latent Interaction (and Moderation) Analysis in Structural Equation Models (SEM)
text: number approaches estimating interaction effects SEM. modsem(), method = "method" argument allows choose use. Different approaches can categorized two groups: Product Indicator (PI) Distribution Analytic (DA) approaches.

title: Latent Interaction (and Moderation) Analysis in Structural Equation Models (SEM)
text: Note constraints can become quite complicated complex models, particularly interaction including enodgenous variables. method can therefore quite slow. "uca" = unconstrained approach (Marsh, 2004) "rca" = residual centering approach (Little et al., 2006) default "pind" = basic product indicator approach (recommended)

title: Latent Interaction (and Moderation) Analysis in Structural Equation Models (SEM)
text: "lms" = Latent Moderated Structural equations (LMS) approach, see vignette "qml" = Quasi Maximum Likelihood (QML) approach, see vignette estimates model Mplus, installed

what: Elementary Interaction Model (Kenny & Judd, 1984; Jaccard & Wan, 1995)

code: library(modsem) m1 <- '   # Outer Model   X =~ x1 + x2 +x3   Y =~ y1 + y2 + y3   Z =~ z1 + z2 + z3      # Inner model   Y ~ X + Z + X:Z  '  # Double centering approach est1_dca <- modsem(m1, oneInt) summary(est1_dca)  # Constrained approach est1_ca <- modsem(m1, oneInt, method = "ca") summary(est1_ca)  # QML approach  est1_qml <- modsem(m1, oneInt, method = "qml") summary(est1_qml, standardized = TRUE)   # LMS approach  est1_lms <- modsem(m1, oneInt, method = "lms")  summary(est1_lms)

title: Latent Interaction (and Moderation) Analysis in Structural Equation Models (SEM)
code: tpb <- " # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)   ATT =~ att1 + att2 + att3 + att4 + att5   SN =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC   BEH ~ PBC:INT "  # double centering approach est_tpb_dca <- modsem(tpb, data = TPB, method = "dblcent") summary(est_tpb_dca)  # Constrained approach using Wrigths path tracing rules for generating # the appropriate constraints est_tpb_ca <- modsem(tpb, data = TPB, method = "ca")  summary(est_tpb_ca)  # LMS approach  est_tpb_lms <- modsem(tpb, data = TPB, method = "lms") summary(est_tpb_lms, standardized = TRUE)   # QML approach  est_tpb_qml <- modsem(tpb, data = TPB, method = "qml")  summary(est_tpb_qml, standardized = TRUE)

what: modsem: Latent Interaction (and Moderation) Analysis in Structural Equation Models (SEM) — modsem-package
title: modsem: Latent Interaction (and Moderation) Analysis in Structural Equation Models (SEM) — modsem-package
text: Estimation interaction (.e., moderation) effects latent variables structural equation models (SEM). supported methods : constrained approach (Algina & Moulder, 2001). unconstrained approach (Marsh et al., 2004). residual centering approach (Little et al., 2006). double centering approach (Lin et al., 2010). latent moderated structural equations (LMS) approach (Klein & Moosbrugger, 2000). quasi-maximum likelihood (QML) approach (Klein & Muthén, 2007) (temporarily unavailable) constrained- unconstrained, residual- double centering- approaches estimated via 'lavaan' (Rosseel, 2012), whilst LMS- QML- approaches estimated via 'modsem' self. Alternatively model can estimated via 'Mplus' (Muthén & Muthén, 1998-2017). References: Algina, J., & Moulder, B. C. (2001). doi:10.1207/S15328007SEM0801_3 . "note estimating Jöreskog-Yang model latent variable interaction using 'LISREL' 8.3." Klein, ., & Moosbrugger, H. (2000). doi:10.1007/BF02296338 . "Maximum likelihood estimation latent interaction effects LMS method." Klein, . G., & Muthén, B. O. (2007). doi:10.1080/00273170701710205 . "Quasi-maximum likelihood estimation structural equation models multiple interaction quadratic effects." Lin, G. C., Wen, Z., Marsh, H. W., & Lin, H. S. (2010). doi:10.1080/10705511.2010.488999 . "Structural equation models latent interactions: Clarification orthogonalizing double-mean-centering strategies." Little, T. D., Bovaird, J. ., & Widaman, K. F. (2006). doi:10.1207/s15328007sem1304_1 . "merits orthogonalizing powered product terms: Implications modeling interactions among latent variables." Marsh, H. W., Wen, Z., & Hau, K. T. (2004). doi:10.1037/1082-989X.9.3.275 . "Structural equation models latent interactions: evaluation alternative estimation strategies indicator construction." Muthén, L.K. Muthén, B.O. (1998-2017). "'Mplus' User’s Guide. Eighth Edition." https://www.statmodel.com/. Rosseel Y (2012). doi:10.18637/jss.v048.i02 . "'lavaan': R Package Structural Equation Modeling."

title: modsem: Latent Interaction (and Moderation) Analysis in Structural Equation Models (SEM) — modsem-package
text: Maintainer: Kjell Solem Slupphaug slupphaugkjell@gmail.com (ORCID) contributors: Mehmet Mehmetoglu mehmetm@ntnu.(ORCID) [contributor] Matthias Mittner matthias.mittner@uit.(ORCID) [contributor]

what: Estimate interaction effects in structural equation models (SEMs) — modsem
title: Estimate interaction effects in structural equation models (SEMs) — modsem
text: modsem() function estimating interaction effects latent variables structural equation models (SEMs). Methods estimating interaction effects SEMs can basically split two frameworks: 1. Product Indicator-based approaches ("dblcent", "rca", "uca", "ca", "pind") 2. Distributionally based approaches ("lms", "qml"). product indicator-based approaches, modsem() essentially fancy wrapper lavaan::sem() generates necessary syntax variables estimation models latent product indicators. distributionally based approaches implemented separately estimated using lavaan::sem(), rather using custom functions (largely written C++ performance reasons). greater control, advised use one sub-functions (modsem_pi, modsem_da, modsem_mplus) directly, passing additional arguments via modsem() can lead unexpected behavior.

title: Estimate interaction effects in structural equation models (SEMs) — modsem

text: modsem_da() function estimating interaction effects latent variables structural equation models (SEMs) using distributional analytic (DA) approaches. Methods estimating interaction effects SEMs can basically split two frameworks: 1. Product Indicator-based approaches ("dblcent", "rca", "uca", "ca", "pind") 2. Distributionally based approaches ("lms", "qml"). modsem_da() handles latter can estimate models using QML LMS, necessary syntax, variables estimation models latent product indicators. NOTE: Run default_settings_da see default arguments.

"qml" = quasi maximum likelihood estimation latent model structural equations (passed lavaan). verbose estimation progress shown optimize starting parameters optimized nodes number quadrature nodes (points integration) used lms, increased number gives better estimates slower computation. many needed depends complexity model. simple models, somewhere 16-24 nodes enough; complex models, higher numbers may needed. models interaction effect endogenous exogenous variable, number nodes least 32, practically (e.g., ordinal/skewed data), 32 recommended. cases data non-normal, might better use qml approach instead. large numbers nodes, might want change 'quad.range' argument. convergence.abs Absolute convergence criterion. Lower values give better estimates slower computation. relevant using QML approach. LMS approach EM-algorithm stops whenever relative absolute convergence criterion reached. convergence.rel Relative convergence criterion. Lower values give better estimates slower computation. LMS approach EM-algorithm stops whenever relative absolute convergence criterion reached. optimizer optimizer use, can either "nlminb" "L-BFGS-B". LMS, "nlminb" recommended. QML, "L-BFGS-B" may faster large number iterations, slower iterations. center.data data centered fitting model standardize.data data scaled fitting model, overridden standardize standardize set TRUE. NOTE: recommended estimate model normally standardize output using standardize_model standardized_estimates, summary(<modsem_da-object>, standardize=TRUE) standardize.output standardized (note alter relationships parameter constraints since parameters scaled unevenly, even label). alter estimation model, output. NOTE: recommended estimate model normally standardize output using standardized_estimates. standardize standardize data fitting model, remove mean structure observed variables, standardize output. Note standardize.data, mean.observed, standardize.overridden standardize standardize set TRUE. NOTE: recommended estimate model normally standardize output using standardized_estimates. mean.observed mean structure observed variables estimated? overridden standardize standardize set TRUE. NOTE: recommended unless know . cov.syntax model syntax implied covariance matrix (see vignette("interaction_two_etas", "modsem")) double try double number dimensions integration used LMS, extremely slow similar mplus. calc.se standard errors computed? NOTE: FALSE, information matrix computed either. FIM Fisher information matrix calculated using observed expected values? Must either "observed" "expected". EFIM.S expected Fisher information matrix computed, EFIM.S selects number Monte Carlo samples. Defaults 100. NOTE: number likely increased better estimates (e.g., 1000), might drasticly increase computation time. OFIM.hessian Logical. TRUE (default) standard errors   based negative Hessian (observed Fisher information).   FALSE come outer product   individual score vectors (OPG). correctly specified models,   two matrices asymptotically equivalent; yielding nearly identical   standard errors large samples. Hessian usually shows smaller finite-sample   variance (.e., consistent), therefore default. Note, Hessian always positive definite, computationally   expensive calculate. OPG always positive definite, lot   faster compute. model correctly specified, sample size large,   two yield similar results, switching OPG can save   lot time. Note, required sample size depends complexity model. large difference Hessian OPG suggests misspecification,   robust.se = TRUE set obtain sandwich (robust) standard errors. EFIM.parametric data calculating expected Fisher information matrix simulated parametrically (simulated based assumptions implied parameters model), non-parametrically (stochastically sampled)? believe normality assumptions violated, EFIM.parametric = FALSE might better option. robust.se robust standard errors computed, using sandwich estimator? R.max Maximum population size (sample size) used calculated expected fischer information matrix. max.iter maximum number iterations. max.step maximum steps M-step EM algorithm (LMS). start starting parameters. epsilon finite difference numerical derivatives. quad.range range z-scores perform numerical integration LMS using, using quasi-adaptive Gaussian-Hermite Quadratures. default Inf, f(t) integrated -Inf Inf, likely inefficient pointless large number nodes. Nodes outside +/- quad.range ignored. adaptive.quad quasi adaptive quadrature used? TRUE, quadrature nodes adapted data. FALSE, quadrature nodes fixed. Default FALSE. adaptive quadrature fit adaptive quadrature participant, instead tries place nodes posterior distribution highest. Compared fixed Gauss Hermite quadrature usually means less nodes placed tails distribution. adaptive.frequency often quasi-adaptive quadrature calculated? Defaults 3, meaning recalculated every third EM-iteration. n.threads number cores use parallel processing. NULL, use <= 2 threads. integer specified, use number threads (e.g., n.threads = 4 use 4 threads). "default", use default number threads (2). "max", use available threads, "min" use 1 thread. algorithm algorithm use EM algorithm. Can either "EM" "EMA". "EM" standard EM algorithm. "EMA" accelerated EM procedure uses Quasi-Newton Fisher Scoring optimization steps needed. Default "EM". em.control list control parameters EM algorithm. See default_settings_da defaults. rcs latent variable indicators replaced reliablity-corrected single item indicators instead? See relcorr_single_item. rcs.choose latent variables get indicators replaced reliablity-reliability corrected single items? title: Interaction between latent variables using lms and qml approaches — modsem_da
code: library(modsem) # For more examples, check README and/or GitHub. # One interaction m1 <- "   # Outer Model   X =~ x1 + x2 +x3   Y =~ y1 + y2 + y3   Z =~ z1 + z2 + z3    # Inner model   Y ~ X + Z + X:Z "  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # QML Approach est_qml <- modsem_da(m1, oneInt, method = "qml") summary(est_qml)  # Theory Of Planned Behavior tpb <- " # Outer Model (Based on Hagger et al., 2007)   ATT =~ att1 + att2 + att3 + att4 + att5   SN =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model (Based on Steinmetz et al., 2011)   # Covariances   ATT ~~ SN + PBC   PBC ~~ SN   # Causal Relationships   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC   BEH ~ INT:PBC "  # LMS Approach est_lms <- modsem_da(tpb, data = TPB, method = lms) summary(est_lms) } # }

title: Plot Interaction Effects in a SEM Model — plot_interaction
text: function creates interaction plot outcome variable (y) function focal predictor (x) multiple values moderator (z). designed use structural equation modeling (SEM) objects (e.g., modsem). Predicted means (predicted individual values) calculated via simple_slopes, plotted ggplot2 display multiple regression lines confidence/prediction bands.

title: Plot Interaction Effects in a SEM Model — plot_interaction
code: plot_interaction(   x,   z,   y,   xz = NULL,   vals_x = seq(-3, 3, 0.001),   vals_z,   model,   alpha_se = 0.15,   digits = 2,   ci_width = 0.95,   ci_type = "confidence",   rescale = TRUE,   standardized = FALSE,   ... )

title: Plot Interaction Effects in a SEM Model — plot_interaction
text: x character string specifying focal predictor (x-axis variable). z character string specifying moderator variable. y character string specifying outcome (dependent) variable. xz character string specifying interaction term (x:z). NULL, term created automatically paste(x, z, sep = ":"). SEM backends may handle interaction term differently (instance, removing modifying colon), function attempts reconcile internally. vals_x numeric vector values compute plot focal predictor x. default seq(-3, 3, .001), provides relatively fine grid smooth lines. rescale=TRUE, values standardized (mean-centered scaled) units, converted back original metric internal computation predicted means. vals_z numeric vector values moderator z draw separate regression lines. distinct value vals_z defines separate group (plotted different color). rescale=TRUE, values also assumed standardized units. model object class modsem_pi, modsem_da, modsem_mplus, possibly lavaan object. Must fitted SEM model containing paths y ~ x + z + x:z. alpha_se numeric value \([0, 1]\) specifying transparency confidence/prediction interval ribbon. Default 0.15. digits integer specifying number decimal places moderator values (z) rounded labeling/grouping plot. ci_width numeric value \((0,1)\) indicating coverage confidence (prediction) interval. default 0.95 95% interval. ci_type character string specifying whether compute "confidence" intervals (mean predicted values, default) "prediction" intervals (include residual variance). rescale Logical. TRUE (default), vals_x vals_z interpreted standardized units, mapped back raw scale computing predictions. FALSE, vals_x vals_z taken raw-scale values directly. standardized coefficients standardized beforehand? ... Additional arguments passed simple_slopes.

title: Plot Interaction Effects in a SEM Model — plot_interaction
text: ggplot object can customized (e.g.,   additional + theme(...) layers). default, shows lines   moderator value shaded region corresponding interval type   (confidence prediction).

title: Plot Interaction Effects in a SEM Model — plot_interaction
text: Computation Steps: Calls simple_slopes compute predicted values y         specified grid x z values. Groups resulting predictions unique z-values (rounded         digits) create colored lines. Plots lines using ggplot2, adding ribbons confidence         (prediction) intervals, transparency controlled alpha_se. Interpretation: line plot corresponds regression y x given level z. shaded region around line (ribbon) shows either confidence interval predicted mean (ci_type = "confidence") prediction interval individual observations (ci_type = "prediction"). ribbons overlap, evidence lines differ significantly range x.

title: Plot Interaction Effects in a SEM Model — plot_interaction
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(modsem)  # Example 1: Interaction of X and Z in a simple SEM m1 <- " # Outer Model   X =~ x1 + x2 + x3   Z =~ z1 + z2 + z3   Y =~ y1 + y2 + y3  # Inner Model   Y ~ X + Z + X:Z " est1 <- modsem(m1, data = oneInt)  # Plot interaction using a moderate range of X and two values of Z plot_interaction(x = "X", z = "Z", y = "Y", xz = "X:Z",                  vals_x = -3:3, vals_z = c(-0.2, 0), model = est1)  # Example 2: Interaction in a theory-of-planned-behavior-style model tpb <- " # Outer Model   ATT =~ att1 + att2 + att3 + att4 + att5   SN  =~ sn1 + sn2   PBC =~ pbc1 + pbc2 + pbc3   INT =~ int1 + int2 + int3   BEH =~ b1 + b2  # Inner Model   INT ~ ATT + SN + PBC   BEH ~ INT + PBC   BEH ~ PBC:INT " est2 <- modsem(tpb, data = TPB, method = "lms")  # Plot with custom Z values and a denser X grid plot_interaction(x = "INT", z = "PBC", y = "BEH",                  xz = "PBC:INT",                  vals_x = seq(-3, 3, 0.01),                  vals_z = c(-0.5, 0.5),                  model = est2) } # }

what: Get the simple slopes of a SEM model — simple_slopes
title: Get the simple slopes of a SEM model — simple_slopes
text: function calculates simple slopes (predicted values outcome variable) user-specified values focal predictor (x) moderator (z) structural equation modeling (SEM) framework. supports interaction terms (xz), computes standard errors (SE), optionally returns confidence prediction intervals predicted values. also provides p-values hypothesis testing. useful visualizing interpreting moderation effects see slope changes different values moderator.

title: Get the simple slopes of a SEM model — simple_slopes

title: Get the simple slopes of a SEM model — simple_slopes
text: x name variable x-axis (focal predictor). z name moderator variable. y name outcome variable. xz name interaction term (x:z). NULL, created combining x z colon (e.g., "x:z"). backends may remove alter colon symbol, function tries account internally. model object class modsem_pi, modsem_da, modsem_mplus, lavaan object. fitted SEM model includes paths y ~ x + z + x:z. vals_x Numeric vector values x compute predicted slopes. Defaults -3:3. rescale = TRUE, values taken relative mean standard deviation x. higher density points (e.g., seq(-3, 3, 0.1)) produce smoother curves confidence bands. vals_z Numeric vector values moderator z compute predicted slopes. Defaults -1:1. rescale = TRUE, values taken relative mean standard deviation z. unique value z generates separate regression line y ~ x | z. rescale Logical. TRUE (default), x z standardized according means standard deviations model. values vals_x vals_z interpreted standardized units. raw (unscaled) values corresponding standardized points displayed returned table. ci_width numeric value 0 1 indicating confidence (prediction) interval width. default 0.95 (.e., 95% interval). ci_type string indicating whether compute "confidence" interval predicted mean (.e., uncertainty regression line) "prediction" interval individual outcomes. default "confidence". "prediction", residual variance added variance fitted mean, resulting wider interval. relative_h0 Logical. TRUE (default), hypothesis tests predicted values (predicted - h0) assume h0 model-estimated mean y. FALSE, null hypothesis h0 = 0. standardized coefficients standardized beforehand? ... Additional arguments passed lower-level functions internal helpers.

title: Get the simple slopes of a SEM model — simple_slopes
text: Computation Steps 1. function extracts parameter estimates (, necessary, covariance    matrix) fitted SEM model (model). 2. identifies coefficients x, z, x:z model's    parameter table, well variance x, z, residual. 3. xz provided, constructed combining x    z colon (":"). certain SEM software, colon may    removed replaced internally; function attempts reconcile . 4. grid x z values created vals_x    vals_z. rescale = TRUE, values transformed back raw    metric units display output. 5. point grid, predicted value y computed via    (beta0 + beta_x * x + beta_z * z + beta_xz * x * z) , included,    mean offset. 6. standard error (std.error) derived covariance matrix    relevant parameters, ci_type = "prediction", adds residual    variance. 7. Confidence (prediction) intervals formed using ci_width (defaulting    95%). result table-like data frame predicted values, CIs,    standard errors, z-values, p-values.

title: Get the simple slopes of a SEM model — simple_slopes
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(modsem)  m1 <- " # Outer Model   X =~ x1 + x2 + x3   Z =~ z1 + z2 + z3   Y =~ y1 + y2 + y3  # Inner model   Y ~ X + Z + X:Z " est1 <- modsem(m1, data = oneInt)  # Simple slopes at X in [-3, 3] and Z in [-1, 1], rescaled to the raw metric. simple_slopes(x = "X", z = "Z", y = "Y", model = est1)  # If the data or user wants unscaled values, set rescale = FALSE, etc. simple_slopes(x = "X", z = "Z", y = "Y", model = est1, rescale = FALSE) } # }

Number Monte Carlo replications use std.errors = "monte.carlo". tolerance.zero Threshold standard errors set NA. correction Logical. Whether apply correction standardized estimates interaction term. default, FALSE, standardizes interaction term \(\sigma^2(XZ) = 1\), consistent lavaan's treatment latent interactions. usually wrong, account fact interaction term product two variables, means variance interaction term standardized variables (usually) equal 1. Hence scale interaction effect changes, standardized interaction term correspond one (standardized) unit change moderating variables. TRUE correction applied, computing interaction term \(b_3 = \frac{B_3 \sigma(X) \sigma(Z)}{\sigma(Y)}\) (\(B_3\) unstandardized coefficient interaction term), solving \(\sigma(XZ)\), used correct variance interaction term, covariances. std.errors Character string indicating method used compute standard errors correction = TRUE. Options include: "rescale" Simply rescales standard errors. Fastest option. "delta" Uses delta method approximate standard errors. "monte.carlo" Uses Monte Carlo simulation estimate standard errors. Ignored correction = FALSE. colon.pi Logical. TRUE, interaction terms output formatted using : seperate elements interaction term. Default FALSE, using default formatting lavaan. relevant std.errors != "rescale" correction == TRUE.
